pullRequest.body:
We prove the Second-Derivative test from calculus using the First-Derivative test.
Source: [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derivative_test#Proof_of_the_second-derivative_test).


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body: messageFile.md
This should be ready for review.

Having taken a more thorough look here, I've revised my previous recommendations and made my new suggestions on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/116395-maths/topic/Second.20Derivative.20Test/near/489113706).
messageFile.md
messageFile.md
messageFile.md
messageFile.md
(you can fix the bot's messages by merging master)

### PR summary [e108beaeaf](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18266/commits/e108beaeaf425311c3d20d1dd64552c165995514)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.Calculus.SecondDerivativeTest` (new file)|1794|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ eventually_nhdsWithin_sign_eq_of_deriv_neg`
`+ eventually_nhdsWithin_sign_eq_of_deriv_pos`
`+ insert_Ioo`
`+ isLocalMax_of_deriv_deriv_neg`
`+ isLocalMin_of_deriv_deriv_pos`
`+ neg_of_slope_neg`
`+ neg_of_slope_pos`
`+ pos_of_slope_pos`
`+ slope_pos_iff`
`+ slope_pos_iff_gt`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Thanks --- new version ready. @fpvandoorn / @j-loreaux
Here are some more comments.

1. I'll have a detailed look at the proofs later when I have a few minutes.
2. I'm concerned that this is only the single variable version of this result. It seems it would be better to have a more general version, but I'll let someone more familiar with the calculus end of the library comment.

1. I'll have a detailed look at the proofs later when I have a few minutes.
2. I'm concerned that this is only the single variable version of this result. It seems it would be better to have a more general version, but I'll let someone more familiar with the calculus end of the library comment.
Here are some more comments. I agree with @j-loreaux that `Filter.Eventually` should be used more here (also in the lemmas I didn't comment on).
Here are some more comments.
I don't understand `₀` in the name.

I think this is the same as
```suggestion
lemma slopeSimpPos {b : ℝ} (hb : x₀ < b) (hbf : 0 < slope (deriv f) x₀ b)
```
Thanks, yes --- really not sure why I wrote it like that!

```suggestion
lemma deriv_pos_of_lt_of_slope_pos {b : ℝ} (hb : x₀ < b) (hbf : 0 < slope (deriv f) x₀ b)
```
or similar. I think presumably every lemma in this PR has a dual for when the slope is negative, so at least you should ensure you leave room for both names.
Thanks, I have tried to improve the names in that vein now.
Is this `DifferentiableWithinAt`?

Well, I just stated it in a way that seemed useful in order to prove the 2nd derivative test below. But now that you mention it, this lemma is really all about `ne` rather than `lt` and `gt` so I have restated the lemma in a new version.
It seems like we should have all the `Ixx` versions of this if we don't already.
This lemma doesn't seem necessary to me. I'm betting there is a much shorter proof and you can simply inline it. I'll check later when I'm at a computer.
I think this should be phrased as "eventually in a punctured neighborhood, the sign of `deriv f b` matches the sign of `b - x`."

```suggestion
lemma slope_pos_iff_gt {𝕜} [LinearOrderedField 𝕜] {f : 𝕜 → 𝕜} {x₀ b : 𝕜} (hb : b < x₀) :
    0 < slope f x₀ b ↔ f b < f x₀ := by
  rw [slope_comm, slope_pos_iff hb]
```
Thanks @fpvandoorn I was able to make that work. (I've been neglecting @j-loreaux 's helpful comments for a month, but this helps with moving things forward!)

I would rewrite this lemma as 
```suggestion
lemma slope_pos_iff {𝕜} [LinearOrderedField 𝕜] {f : 𝕜 → 𝕜} {x₀ b : 𝕜} (hb : x₀ < b) :
    0 < slope f x₀ b ↔ f x₀ < f b := by
  simp [slope, hb]
```

All hypotheses should probably just be replaced by a single `(h : ∀ᶠ b in 𝓝[≠] x₀, deriv f b ≠ 0)`, but then this lemma becomes trivial, since the proof is `h.mono <| fun _ ↦ differentiableAt_of_deriv_ne_zero`, and should probably just be removed.
Yes, makes sense. New version incoming.
This currently states the same as the previous lemma. I think you can delete this unless you actually use it.
Isn't the proof here `rwa [slope_pos_iff_gt, hf] at hbf` (untested)?
Here and below: generalize `ℝ` to `LinearOrderedField`
These basic slope lemmas probably deserve to be in a more basic file. Can you find or create a good place for them? (cf. `#min_imports`)
Can you prove this from `isLocalMin_of_deriv_deriv_pos` applied to `-f`?

This proof is still somewhat long, even though you're essentially there.
I think it makes sense to either
- reformulate `eventually_nhdsWithin_sign_eq_of_deriv_pos` so that it is closer to `isLocalMin_of_deriv` (as 2 separate lemmas)
- reformulate `isLocalMin_of_deriv` so that it's closer to `eventually_nhdsWithin_sign_eq_of_deriv_pos` (e.g. 1 assumption involving `sign` instead of the last 3 assumptions).

pullRequest.title: feat: Second-derivative test from calculus

nodes.body: messageFile.md
This should be ready for review.

1. I'll have a detailed look at the proofs later when I have a few minutes.
2. I'm concerned that this is only the single variable version of this result. It seems it would be better to have a more general version, but I'll let someone more familiar with the calculus end of the library comment.

Having taken a more thorough look here, I've revised my previous recommendations and made my new suggestions on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/116395-maths/topic/Second.20Derivative.20Test/near/489113706).
Here are some more comments. I agree with @j-loreaux that `Filter.Eventually` should be used more here (also in the lemmas I didn't comment on).
messageFile.md
